name: Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad
architects: AC Norman, RAJ Bidwell, CE Spooner, AB Hubback
info: This was the Government Offices of the British Colonial administration. The two-storey building is 480ft long with a wide arched colonnade. The imposing clock tower rises to over 140ft. It now holds the offices of the National Heritage Department.

name: Old Post Office
info: Designed by AB Hubback at a cost of $100,000 (Straits Dollars), its style is similar to the Sultan Abdul Samad building. It remained the General Post Office until 1984 and is now used by the Ministry of Tourism and Culture.

name: Wisma Straits Trading, Loke Yew Building & Chow Kit & Co. Building
architects: B.M. Iversen (Loke Yew Bldg), AK Moosden (Chow Kit Bldg)
info: This group includes the Loke Yew Building, an iconic six-storey Art Deco structure, and the Chow Kit & Co. Building, built in a Neo-Renaissance style. The latter was adapted for new use as the Industrial Court of Malaysia.

name: Masjid Jamek
info: Located on the site of a Malay cemetery at the confluence of the Klang and Gombak rivers. The design is said to be inspired by North Indian Moghul mosques. It was the main mosque in KL until Masjid Negara opened in 1965.

name: Medan Pasar (Old Market Square)
info: This was the original township center with Kapitan Yap Ah Loy's market. The Art Deco Clock Tower in the center was erected in 1937 to commemorate the coronation of King George VI.

name: Sze Ya Temple
info: The oldest traditional Chinese temple in the city. The board at the entrance attributes Kapitan Yap Ah Loy as the founder in 1864. It is dedicated to the patron deities of Sin Sze Ya and Si Sze Ya.

name: The Triangle (Bangkok Bank Triangle)
info: This triangle is formed by the conjunction of Jalan Tun HS Lee and Jalan Petaling. It features several distinctive shophouses, such as the unique Old Federal Stores Building.

name: Kedai Ubat Kwong Ban Heng
info: Located at No 62, Jalan Tun Perak. Established over 30 years ago, it retains many traditional fixtures and fittings, such as glass cabinets and shelving.

name: Oriental Building
info: One of KL's distinctive heritage buildings. At five storeys, it was the tallest in Kuala Lumpur at that time. It originally housed Radio Malaya and is now leased by CIMB Bank.

name: Flower Garland Stalls
info: Located across the street from the Oriental Building, near the Teochew Association. These stalls are where you can learn how to make a traditional flower garland.

name: Masjid India
info: Began as a timber building in 1893. The new mosque, which can accommodate 3,500 people, was opened in 1966. It is built in the Southern Indian style.

name: P.H. Hendry Royal Jewellers
info: The oldest existing jewellers in Malaysia. They were appointed royal jewellers to the Sultans of Selangor, Kelantan, and Negeri Sembilan in the 1920s.

name: Panggong Bandaraya (Old City Hall)
info: Designed by AB Hubback, this building originally housed the Kuala Lumpur Town Hall. Architecturally, it carries the Moghul style of the Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad.

name: Dataran Merdeka
info: Originally known as the Padang. At the stroke of midnight on 31 August 1957, the Union Jack was lowered here, and Malaya became an independent nation.

name: National Textile Museum
info: Originally built as the FMS Railway Offices. The fa√ßade is in the Moghul style with distinctive red and white banding, achieved by alternating fair-faced bricks with plastered bricks.

name: OCBC Building
info: This Art Deco building was the headquarters of the OCBC. The design was innovative for its time as it provided basement storage for bicycles.

name: Central Market (Pasar Seni)
info: This Art Deco building served as KL's wholesale wet market until the mid-1980s. It was restored and adapted into an art and culture market in 1986.

name: Jalan Yap Ah Loy
info: A short road with high historical significance, it led to Kapitan Yap Ah Loy's house on Lebuh Pasar Besar.

name: Lebuh Ampang
info: This street still has many Indian restaurants, spice stores, and money-lenders. It was the street of the Chettiar, a south Indian caste of money-lenders.

name: Jalan Melaka
info: Walking up this street, you pass major modern buildings like Bank Muamalat, which has a banking hall built following the design of a traditional Malay House.

name: Selangor Mansion & Malayan Mansion
info: An early example of mass public housing. These are eight-storey buildings with retail on the ground floor and 160 residential flats on the subsequent floors.

name: Wisma Yakin
info: An 11-storey building developed by Malay entrepreneurs supported by PKNS. It remains the 'must-go' place to buy Baju Melayu or songkok.

name: Jalan Melayu
info: Also known as Malay Street, this was named for the Malay settlers in the area. A prominent owner from the 1870s was Haji Mohamed Eusop bin Abubakar.

name: Batu Road (Jalan TAR)
info: Now Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman (Jalan TAR). It was so named because it began as a track leading to the limestone caves and tin mines at Batu.

name: Old Survey Office
info: Designed by AB Hubback, this building features a dramatic 400 ft (121.6m) long arcade along Jalan Tun Perak. It was later turned into the Sessions and Magistrates Courts.

name: Old High Court
info: Also designed by AB Hubback, it replaced the Supreme Courts which had been located on Court Hill. The public entrance faces the river and leads to a grand inner courtyard.
